questions.text: Which of the following is an RNA-based sequencing technique?
questions.solution:
RT PCR USES RNA AS THE BASE TEMPLATE

SANGER IS A SEQUENCING TECHNIQUE

Sequencing Technique

  • Sequence the entire chromosome/gene

There are 2 ways:

  1. Sanger sequencing (old)
  2. NGS: Next generation sequencing (New)

Entire human chromosome can be sequenced

Done as human genome project (HGP)

G BANDING IS TYPE OF KARYOTYPING

SOUTH BLOT IS FOR DNA , NOT USED NOWADAYS

questions.solution: • Since a male transmit only Y chromosome to his son, so answer is holandric or Y linked inheritance :e.g hypertrichosis

questions.text: A 62-year-old man has had increasing knee pain with movement for the past 10 years. The knee joint surfaces are eroded and the joint space narrowed. There is loss of compressibility and lubrication of articular cartilaginous surfaces. Loss of which of the following extracellular matrix components has most likely occurred in this man?
questions.solution: • He has osteoarthritis, or degenerative joint disease, with loss of articular hyaline cartilage. Hyaluronan (hyaluronic acid) is a large mucopolysaccharide, one form of proteoglycan, which forms a hydrated, compressible gel contributing to the shock-absorbing function of joint surfaces. Elastin is a fibrillar protein that provides recoil in tissues such as skin, arterial walls, and ligaments that need to stretch and return to their original shape. Fibronectin is a form of glycoprotein that serves an adhesive function. Integrins are glycoproteins that serve as cellular receptors for extracellular matrix components; they can link to intracellular actin so that cells can alter their shape and mobility. Laminins are a form of glycoprotein that help to anchor epithelial surfaces in basement membranes.

choices.text: Immune complex deposition followed by inflammation
Eosinophil activation and mediated tissue injury
Cytokine secretion from Helper T cells

questions.text: The following is a diagnostic test done to look for previous exposure to an infectious agent. What causes a positive test interpretation in this test?
questions.solution:
• Clinical Example of CD4+T Cell-Mediated Inflammatory Reactions.
  • The classic example of DTH is the tuberculin reaction(known in clinical medicine as the PPD skin test), which is produced by the intracutaneous injection of purified protein derivative(PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacillus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to causality complaining easy tiredness and weakness since 1 year. CBC performed shows high TLC and automated differential counts suggested monocytosis. Peripheral smear examination was done and shown below. Based on characteristic features what is your probable diagnosis
questions.solution: The nuclear size and shape in the abnormal promyelocytes of the hypergranular APML are of then bilobed and kidney shaped. The cytoplasm of these cells have dense granules obscuring the nuclear border. Characteristics cells have bundle of Auer rod in their cytoplasm called as faggot cells.

choices.text: Only i, ii, and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct

questions.text:
Which is/are the factors affect rate and degree of sickling in sickle cell disease?
i) Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
ii) Haemoglobin S level
iii) Haemoglobin F level
iv) Mean corpuscular hemoglobin
questions.solution:
Following factors determine the rate at which the polymerization of HbS and consequent sickling take place:

  1. Presence of non HbShemoglobin
  2. Intracellular concentration of HbS
  3. Total hemoglobin concentration
  4. Extent of deoxygenation
  5. Acidosis and dehydration
  6. Increased concentration of 2, 3 BPG in the red cells

choices.text: Deficiency of folate reductase in CNS
Folate therapy caused rapid use of B12 stores aggravating symptoms

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came with complaints of easy fatigability, exertion dyspnea and weight loss. She also complaints of frequent fall. Physical Examination revealed there was bilateral decrease in vibration sense. Her hemoglobin levels were 8.2 gm%. She was treated with folate. Her anemia improved but neurological symptoms worsened. Which of the following is the most probable reason for her condition?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12

  • Major role in providing cofactors that are required to form myelin.
  • Required for the production of methionine (precursor for S-adenosyl methionine), which is required for methylation reaction.
  • Myelin maintenance and nerve function.
  • Demyelination occurs from vitamin B12 deficiency. Neurological problems occur in most people who are deficient in vitamin B12.
  • Folic acid can usually correct the anemia. Thus it could mask the underlying disease, and allow the development or progression of neurological deterioration, if diagnosis depended on the presence of anaemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with fever and painful joints for 2 weeks. Physical examination shows skin pigmentation, glossitis, angular cheilitis, and generalized lymphadenopathy. The patient has lost 9 kg (20 lb) over the past 6 months. He reports that his stools are pale and foul smelling. Blood cultures are negative. The patient is started on antibiotic therapy and exhibits remarkable clinical improvement. Biopsy of the small intestine is taken and histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Biopsy of the small intestine shows marked distortion of the intestinal villi and numerous foamy macrophages suggestive of Whipple disease. It's a rare infectious disorder of the small intestine in which malabsorption is the most prominent feature. The disorder typically features infiltration of the small bowel mucosa by macrophages that are packed with small, rod-shaped bacilli (Tropherymawhipplei). Infiltrate of macrophages containing bacilli may be found in other organs, including regional lymph nodes and the heart. The other choices do not feature these distinctive aggregates of foamy macrophages.

questions.text: FISH is done in which her2 neu status:

A 42-year-old man with AIDS dementia complex dies of respiratory insufficiency secondary to Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia. Examination of the brain at autopsy reveals mild cerebral atrophy, with dilation of the lateral ventricles. Which of the cells are the main culprit for the neuropathologic changes?
questions.solution: In most patients with AIDS encephalopathy, the disease is attributable to an active infection of the CNS by the virus itself. Macrophages and microglial cells in the CNS are productively infected by HIV-1. Although neurons and astrocytes may interact with the virus, they do not seem to be infected but are injured indirectly by cytokines or other neurotoxic factors released by macrophages. Also only microglia cells express both CD 4 co-receptor and chemokines receptor (CCR5 and CXCR4) that are required in combination for efficient infection by HIV.

questions.text: Life span of transfused platelets?
Which of the following blood components has the shortest shelf life?
questions.solution:
Shelf life for various components

Red blood cells 35-42 days

Platelets 5-7 days

Fresh frozen plasma 1 year

Cryoprecipitate 1 year

questions.text: Which disease is transmitted by all the components of blood?

A 23-year-old man complains of nasal obstruction, bloody nose, cough, and bloody sputum. A chest X-ray displays cavitated lesions and multiple nodules within both lung fields. Urinalysis reveals 3+ hematuria and red blood cell casts. Laboratory studies show anemia and elevated serum levels of C-ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody). Peripheral eosinophils are not increased. A renal biopsy was performed and histopathological image is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological images shows crescent which is seen in rapidly proliferative glomerulonephritis.

  • The classic histologic picture is one of enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli. The hypercellularity is caused by
    1. Infiltration by leukocytes, both neutrophils and monocytes;
    2. Proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.
  • The glomeruli often show focal and segmental necrosis, and variably show diffuse or focal endothelial proliferation, and mesangial proliferation. Segmental glomerular necrosis and distinctive crescents.
  • In classic MPGN, histologic picture is one of enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli. The hypercellularity is caused by
    1. Infiltration by leukocytes, both neutrophils and monocytes;
    2. Proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.
  • By light microscopy, the glomeruli either appears normal in the early stages of the disease or exhibit uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male chronic smoker patient presented with respiratory difficulties these days which usually gradually increasing since 2 months. Chest X-ray and CT scan show a mass in the periphery of left lung. Transbronchial lung biopsy was performed and based the histopathological features diagnosis of small cell carcinoma was given. To confirm your diagnosis which IHC will show positive expression?
questions.solution: Specific markers associated with adenocarcinoma (TTF-1, napsin A) or squamous cell carcinoma (p40, p63), neuroendocrine tumor, small cell carcinoma (Synaptophysin, NSE).

questions.text: A post renal transplant patient presented with complaints of chronic renal failure. As a part of investigative workup, the patient urine microscopy suggested the following finding, identify the structure marked by arrow.
questions.solution: The given figure shows urine cytology in samples obtained during clinical rejection showing numerous renal tubular cells, lymphocytes, and macrophages along with few Hyaline casts (as shown in the arrow).

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of inflammosome?
questions.solution:
NOD-like receptors (NLRs) are cytosolic receptors named after the founding member NOD-2. They recognize a wide variety of substances, including products released from necrotic or damaged cells (e.g., uric acid and adenosine triphosphate [ATP]), loss of intracellular K+ ions, and some microbial products. NOD like receptor (NLRs) signal via a cytosolic multiprotein complex called the INFLAMMASOME, which activates an enzyme (caspase-1) that cleaves a precursor form of the cytokine interleukin-1 (IL-1) to generate the biologically active form. Caspase 1 is a critical component of the inflammasome, responsible for activating pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1β and IL-18.

Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • a) Caspase 9: Involved in the intrinsic apoptotic pathway, not the inflammasome.
  • c) Caspase 3: Plays a role in apoptosis execution, not directly linked to the inflammasome.
  • d) All of the above: Incorrect because only Caspase 1 is a component of the inflammasome.

Key Takeaways: Inflammasomes are multiprotein complexes that play a crucial role in the innate immune response by activating inflammatory caspases, specifically Caspase 1. Caspase 1 is involved in the processing of pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1β and IL-18, which are key players in inflammation. Caspase 9 and Caspase 3 are involved in apoptosis, not the inflammasome.

questions.text: From the following image of chromosomal translocation and associated oncogene, choose the correct diagnosis for red box.
questions.solution:
In Burkitt lymphoma, the MYC gene is translocated into an antigen receptor gene locus, which contains gene regulatory elements called enhancers that are highly active in lymphocytes.

  • Burkitt lymphoma is an aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by MYC gene dysregulation.
  • The hallmark of this malignancy is the translocation of the MYC proto-oncogene on chromosome 8 to regions under the control of immunoglobulin (Ig) gene enhancers.

Pathophysiology

  • The Ig enhancers drive constitutive overexpression of MYC, leading to:
    1. Uncontrolled Cell Proliferation:
      • MYC upregulates cyclins and other genes promoting the cell cycle.
    2. Inhibition of Apoptosis:
      • Interferes with apoptotic pathways, such as through downregulation of BCL-2 inhibitors.
    3. Metabolic Reprogramming:
      • Increases glycolysis and biosynthesis to support rapid cell division.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In Burkitt lymphoma, translocations involving the MYC gene lead to its dysregulated overexpression, driving tumorigenesis. Prompt diagnosis through cytogenetic and molecular testing is critical for initiating effective therapy.

questions.text: What is the most common gene mutation in pancreatic solid pseudopapillary neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Somatic point mutation of β catenin gene (CTNNB1) is present in > 90% of pancreatic solid pseudopapillary neoplasms

  • Hamoudi or Frantz tumor or solid pseudopapillary pancreatic tumor is a tumor of Low malignant potential tumors with unclear cell of origin and pathogenesis
  • Presents in younger women, classically as solitary body / tail mass
  • Variable amount of solid and cystic areas grossly
  • Papillary fronds on myxoid or hyalinized vascular stalk lined by poorly cohesive, uniform cells with nuclear grooves comprising solid and cystic areas beta catenin nuclear / cytoplasmic positive

Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following receptor(s) has/have phagocytic properties?
i. Scavenger receptors
ii. Mechano receptors
iii. Mannose receptors
iv. Chemoreceptors
questions.solution:
• Phagocytosis involves three sequential steps:
    1. Recognition and attachment of the particle to be ingested by the leukocyte.
    2. Engulfment, with subsequent formation of a phagocytic vacuole.
    3. Killing or degradation of the ingested material.
  • These steps are triggered by activation of phagocytes by microbes, necrotic debris and various mediators.
  • Mannose receptors, scavenger receptors and receptors for various opsonins bind and ingest microbes.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female patient presented to the emergency department with history of abdominal pain which is associated frequently on and off vomiting. Ultrasound performed shows presence of gallstones and patient was planned for cholecystectomy. PAC examination shows HBsAg positivity with value of 4.42 IU by ELISA method. Further investigations revealed presence of HBeAg. If Liver biopsy performed at this time, it will show all the following features; except:
questions.solution:
• HBeAg, HBV DNA, and HBV DNA polymerase are detectable in the serum soon after HBsAg and signify active viral replication. (a & b) Microscopically, there is a portal and lobular inflammatory infiltrate comprised predominantly of lymphocytes and variably admixed with plasma cells and eosinophils.

(c) In chronic hepatitis B, the swollen endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes are swollen and filled with HBsAg, leading to a "ground-glass" appearance.

(d) The hepatocyte injury may result in necrosis or apoptosis. Necrosis of groups of hepatocytes (i.e., confluent necrosis) may be seen in severe cases and can progress to necrosis of the entire lobule (i.e., panlobular or panacinar necrosis) or connect vascular structures (i.e., bridging necrosis).

choices.text: It results from delayed type hypersensitivity response
Histopathological examination will reveal dense transmural inflammatory infiltrate
Pathological changes are systemic and significantly affect kidney and liver
Immunoglobulin and aspirin therapy improve the symptoms

questions.text: A 2-year-old male baby presented with redness of eye, erythema of hand and feet along with cervical lymph node enlargement. He also complains of presence of fever. Based on the above clinical findings, all of the following statements are true regarding the disease except:
questions.solution:
(a) The vasculitis may result from a delayed-type hypersensitivity response directed against cross-reactive or newly uncovered vascular antigens.

(b) Kawasaki disease vasculitis resembles that seen in PAN. There is a dense transmural inflammatory infiltrate, although the fibrinoid necrosis is usually less prominent than in PAN.

(c) Pathologic changes outside the cardiovascular system are rarely significant.

(d) Immunoglobulin and aspirin therapy improve the symptoms, it's true.

questions.text: Activation of proapoptotic proteins by BH3-only sensors, possibly direct activation of caspases. Which of the following pathological condition correlates with this mechanism of apoptosis?
Which of the following gives moth eaten appearance in the cytoplasm of necrotic cell?
questions.solution:
• Necrosis is characterized by changes in the cytoplasm and nuclei of the injured cells.
  • Necrotic cells show increased eosinophilia(i.e., they are stained red by the dye eosin), attributable partly to increased binding of eosin to denatured cytoplasmic proteins and partly to loss of basophilic ribonucleic acid(RNA) in the cytoplasm(basophilia stems from binding of the blue dye hematoxylin).
  • Compared with viable cells, the cell may have a glassy, homogeneous appearance, mostly because of the loss of lighter staining glycogen particles.
  • Myelin figures are more prominent in necrotic cells than in cells with reversible injury.
  • When enzymes have digested cytoplasmic organelles, the cytoplasm becomes vacuolated and appears "moth-eaten."

choices.text: This is image of fat necrosis
It occurs when fatty acids are generated that combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas
Deposits of these immune complexes, together with plasma proteins can cause this
Acute pancreatitis can also show this change due to lipases

questions.text: 50 year old female came with breast lump. on resection, following was seen. what is not true about the image shown
questions.solution: Fat necrosis refers to focal areas of fat destruction, typically resulting from release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. This occurs in the calamitous abdominal emergency known as acute pancreatitis due to lipases. In this disorder, pancreatic enzymes leak out of damaged acinar cells and liquefy the membranes of fat cells in the peritoneum, releasing triglyceride esters that are split by pancreatic lipases. Fatty acids are generated that combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas(fat saponification), which enable the surgeon and the pathologist to identify the underlying disorder.

questions.text: Image shown is one of the initiation pathways of apoptosis. Which of the following molecule inhibits this pathway?
questions.solution:
FLIP inhibits Fas mediated apoptosis.

This extrinsic apoptosis pathway can be inhibited by a protein called FLIP, which binds to procaspase- 8, thereby blocking FADD binding, but cannot activate the caspase. Some viruses and normal cells produce FLIP as a mechanism to protect themselves from Fasmediated apoptosis

questions.text: The apoptosis is regulated by anti and pro-apoptotic Bcl 2 family of protein. Which of the following is the anti-apoptotic protein?
questions.solution:
• Anti-apoptotic: BCL-2, BCL-XL, MCL-1
  • Pro-apoptotic: BAD, BIM, BID, PUMA, P53 and NOXA.

choices.text: Injury decreases if intracellular ferrous levels decrease

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about ferroptosis
questions.solution: Ferroptosis is a distinct form of cell death that is triggered when excessive intracellular levels of iron or reactive oxygen species overwhelm the glutathione-dependent antioxidant defenses. Hence ferroptosis usually involves loss of glutathione. Ultrastructurally, the most prominent features are the loss of mitochondrial cristae and ruptured outer mitochondrial membrane

questions.text: Histological picture of a lesion excised from the right cervical region is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Epithelioid macrophages differ from ordinary macrophages in that they have elongated nuclei that often resemble the sole of a slipper or shoe.

  • IFN-gamma is important in activating macrophages and trans-forming them into epithelioid cells and multinucleate giant cells with caseous necrosis

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is recovering from skin infection with crusts formation. The crusts are removed, and a culture of the lesions shows Streptococcus pyogenes. He is treated with antibiotics. One week later, he develops malaise with nausea and a slight fever and passes dark brown urine. Kidney biopsy performed at this stage is shown below, based on your diagnosis electron microscopy will show amorphous deposition at:
questions.solution:
• The classic histologic picture is one of enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli. The hypercellularity is caused by
    1. Infiltration by leukocytes, both neutrophils and monocytes;
    2. Proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells suggestive of PSGN.
  • The characteristic electron microscopic findings are discrete, amorphous, electron-dense deposits on the epithelial side of the membrane, often having the appearance of "humps"presumably representing the antigen-antibody complexes at the subepithelial cell surface. Subendothelial deposits are also commonly seen, typically early in the disease course, and mesangial and intramembranous deposits may be present.
